values: My portrait that we entered for Pet Spotlight. Please do not re-post this image, thank you. You can see more of my owner's artwork here: auryanne.deviantart.com

Falcon in the Dive The Scarlet Pimpernel Hunt for the man Comb the city, every street, every grate Put a guard at every gate Drag him out, shout the moment that you find him! Damn! Knock in the doors, lock up the city Track him down through this town And be quick about it...now! How the devil do I ever prevail when I'm only a man? I can never be duped by this scurrilous phantom again I wasn't born to walk on water I wasn't born to sack and slaughter But on my soul, I wasn't born To stoop, to scorn, and knuckle under A man can learn to steal some thunder A man can learn to work some wonder And when the gauntlet's down, It's time to rise and climb the sky And soon the moon will smoulder And the winds will drive Yes, a man grows older but his soul remains alive All those tremulous stars still glitter And I will survive! Let my heart grow colder and as bitter as a falcon in the dive! There was a dream, a dying ember There was a dream, I don't remember But I will resurrect that dream Though rivers stream and hills grow steeper For here in hell where life gets cheaper Oh, here in hell the blood runs deeper And when the final duel is near I'll lift my spear and fly Piercing into the sky and higher And the strong will thrive Yes, the weak will cower while the fittest will survive If we wait for the darkest hour Till we spring alive Then with claws of fire, we devour like a falcon in the dive! These are the days! Yes! Days of glory, days of rage, and the dream And the dream of Paris preys on my bones Gnawing night and day and clawing through my brain and No, never bend! Never kneel! Rend him to bits! Bite! Now, the beauty of the fight I'm not a man to hunger for blood, but the spirit can cry To be younger and fiercer and fly Piercing into the sky and higher And the strong will thrive Yes, the weak will cower while the fittest will survive If we wait for the darkest hour Till we spring alive Then with claws of fire, we devour like a falcon in the dive!

The battle has kept me from writing here; finally there seems to be a break in the line that I may linger long enough to put these words down. Conditions at the front are not terrible, though I can sense morale has slipped these past few days. First the clanking, terrible war machines that lent a new meaning to the word 'destruction', now we turn our swords among innocent peasants fallen under the hag's spell. No good can come of this, it is a slaughter - not a battle, and the troops know it. I pray that soon we may break through the aerial defenses and attack the Citadel directly, though unseasonable - and likely magical - bad weather keeps the troops grounded. I fear also the toll that this battle will take upon our home, already shaken by the pangs of battle not yet a year ago. Certainly Kass has not attended to it with the care and love that we had! It is a tangible symbol of his stolen sovereignty, and no doubt before long he will wish it gone. 

The outlook is bleak, but I have faith that soon our fate will change.

I settle my weary wings for a rest, having fought off fifty bands of those wretched spyders since the day past. I may yet return to the fray later in the day, once I have had time to survey the situation more carefully, and refresh our supplies.

Dear little Ripper is eager to fight, but I will take no chances with him; he is in the care of Lakahari for the time being. Though I worry she may be neglecting him in favor of her own little Malachi, whom I admit is a rather charming creature, though far too undignified for my own taste. 

Hirzok, the young recruit, is showing great promise as well as many other Eyries; it pleases me to see that perhaps more are seeing Kass for the fraud that he truly is!

The storm has broken; Kass's troops -- such as they are! -- are on the attack. I have no love for Skarl, the petulant traitor, yet no more do I wish to see Kass expand his poisonous influence. What sort of a commander orders an attack on simple, unarmed peasants? 

I would think it strange, perhaps, had I time to reflect on the situation, to take up arms for the defense of Meridell. But it is not only for Meridell that we fight -- no, we fight for the honor of our kingdom and to restore our rightful ruler to the throne!
... is alive? My heart assured me so, but now I must see it with my own eyes. My Lord... we have not forgotten!

It would appear that I am more well-known than I first believed!

http://www.neopets.com/search.phtml?selected_type=user&string=_falangorn_

http://www.neopets.com/search.phtml?selected_type=pet&string=_Falangorn_

I realize I have been silent these past days, but it is not for lack of something to say. I am not sure where to begin.

Two nights ago, as the red light fell to black, and the signal fires were lit all along the Citadel walls, I saw something strange - or rather it was the lack of something that I noticed first. The silken banners of Lord Darigan were gone, the spires of the Citadel strangely naked without their adornments. And as I neared I saw a commotion gathered at the Academy where I, my father, and generations before me had been trained in the art of war. There was Kass, smug amidst the smoke and rubble of what was once the Academy's great hall, the confused and angry ranks eyeing him suspiciously. 

You may think me a coward for turning back to the shadows, rather than challenging Kass outright, but you would be wrong. He is supported by his guard and his followers, to attack him would be suicide. No, I have a far better plan; more ignoble in the short term, perhaps, but in the end I believe we will restore the rightful ruler to the throne. 

I dare not write here the location to which I will bring my troops; those who have shown loyalty and candor will be given the signal to join me later. All intruders will be repelled and no quarter given to spies or traitors.

The scouts bring back strange tales of a beast in the farmlands below, destroying crops and frightening the villagers. And if that were not enough, there are strange winds blowing within the Citadel as well. 

Kass, that brazen upstart, fancies himself the new Lord of the Citadel, it would seem! What must be running through his cotton brain, I have no idea. I will hold my tongue for now, however, and see what the winds bring before I act.
*grumbles* I need to persuade that lazy owner of mine to create some new images for me. I do not like having the same icons as everyone else. I am, after all, the Legendary Falangorn!

I hadn't realized it had been quite so long since I've blown the dust off of this old journal. As I am sure you are aware, storm clouds have been gathering around the Citadel, in the guise of one young officer by the name of Kass.

<font size=1>Kass? What sort of name is that for a soldier?!</font>

I, myself, was drafted into a campaign which kept me far from home, and far from those I love for far too long. And as is often the case, when I returned things had irrevocably changed. But I have weathered far worse, and will surely do so again, and now I resume my duties at the Citadel with renewed vigor and hope. 

It pleases me to see that my little Ripper has not forgotten me, even if many others have. I have always known there was something particular in the gleam of that one's eye, and I am grateful to have him.

ROARRRRR!!! General Tarnahk was bad enough... stamping mud all over the carpets and breaking the chairs with his great huge tail, but now we have this -- thing in the moat! It -- or perhaps she, it's difficult to discern -- refuses to come up to the surface and speak like a civilized being, instead glowering at us from beneath the water, or making rude gestures with its fins. Ugh... I would have a stiff mug of mead had that boorish Grarrl not drunk it all already. It's going to be a long evening.
As you may see in my information file, I can now be reached via "instant messenger" - a strange notion if I ever heard one! My name is, of course, "Falangorn".

17th day Relaxing, Y5

Good heavens above, this is awful! I have been searching the Citadel from flags to floor but I can find no trace of Ripper. I have heard rumor that other petpets have been disappearing, but I had presumed they were exaggerated, or that those petpets were unhappy. I speak very little Drackonack, but I am firmly certain that dear Ripper was never unhappy with me. Could someone have stolen into the Citadel in the depths of night to take him away? For what purpose? This is terribly upsetting. Once the sun rises fully, I shall make a sweep of the lands from above, in case he is lost and wandering some place far from home.

Do not fear, Ripper, I will find you!

I am not sure what to make of this fellow. Perhaps some parent found me inspiration enough to name their son after me - I can assure you that he is no blood of mine. Not to mention that he looks nothing like me - no sharp rugged beak or fine lashing tail... hmph.

19th of Hunting, Y5
12:12:32 pm NST

Ah, what a relief it is to be within these Citadel walls once more! Though at times I may find them stifling, after two weeks of battle I am more than happy to rest my weary wings.

While I cannot divulge too much detail, a small band of pirates were sighted above the bay. A small squadron of soldiers were dispatched to run them off, only to be surprised by the rest of the brigands who were lying in wait. Reinforcements were necessary, the dense terrain and the less than noble nature of the enemy made the battle unexpectedly difficult.

Our superior numbers and equipment soon sent the churls fleeing for the hills, with little more than minor scuffles all around. 

It is with anticipation that I return to find our gardens nearing completion, for the Lady Ketawyen I know is fond of the black roses, and with luck they should soon be in the full bloom of summer. The thought had crossed my mind, of course, that I could take them to her, but this idea sends tremors of fear through my very bones. How is it that I can face death without flinching above the battlefields, and at the same time become a trembling fledgling at the memory of the sunlight upon her wings?

I must away, Ripper is needing to be fed.

Yours,
Falangorn
mean bird tel me rite heer he go to fite and be bak sun ripr
A picture of my father and I (as a fledgling - ugh!) which will eventually be on my page. In the meantime, you can look at it here, I guess. Yours (sulking), Falangorn

30th of Eating, Y5
10:16:19 am NST 

As is the way of things, life seems to be returning to something like normal around the Citadel. Of course, hushed rumors echo in the corridors that with the destruction of the Orb, that our kingdom will never again know its former glory. To this I say, "Rubbish!" There is no shame in our appearance, fierce though it may be, possessed of a certain savage beauty... particularly the female Eyries... ah, but I wander again.

For reasons beyond my comprehension, someone (I shall not name names) brought a wretched Turmac into the Citadel yesterday evening. The beast is an unholy terror, eating anything within its grasp and leaving puddles on the fine stonework floors. Thank goodness Ripper hasn't yet come across it, I imagine they would take instant dislike to one another. It has, quite appropriately I think, been named "Skarl" for the time being.

Yours,
Falangorn

These rumors are puzzling and patently untrue. Our Lord at this moment is bellowing at the serving boy for bringing him Carrot Soup instead of Leek and Potato. 

I take this vim and vigor as a sign of his rapid recovery.

Yours,
Falangorn

Ahem.

As you, Gentle Reader, have undoubtedly heard, our revered Lord has not exactly been feeling himself of late.

Following our triumphant victory over the forces of Meridell, our Lord has been acting in a most peculiar manner. This culminated some weeks ago when he appeared to erupt in living flame. (You cannot imagine the chaos this caused with the furnishings.) He has similarly become rather larger than his usual height, and must be confined to the larger chambers of the Citadel. Perhaps most un-nerving of all, he has taken to spontaneous and raucous outburts of maniacal laughter, and he seems to do so at the most inappropriate moments. For example, two days past the cook appeared to explain the substitution of the Kau steaks that were on that evening's menu; when his Lordship suddenly burst out in an eerie cackle, muttering about raining fire and destruction from above.

Please do not mistake my frankness for doubt or uncertainty; my loyalty has been tested before and it surely will be tested hence. I feel that in this, his time of need, I am given the chance to prove the mettle of my character.

The morning past we were concerned to find His Lordship nowhere within the Citadel. Harried with worry, I sent scouts to try and locate him, and to my surprise, received word back that he was engaged in a great battle.

A great battle, without including us! 

His Lordship was splendid to see, his noble profile licked in dancing flame as he struck down wave after wave of attackers. I and his most trusted advisors gathered around to watch, but were helpless to turn back the tide of angry peasants. The fighting raged all day and into the night, and it was only on the afternoon of the following day that our Lord's strength began to fail him, and he collapsed upon the ground with a great shuddering. 

It took an effort by all to bring him safely back to the Citadel, and he now rests within his impromptu chambers. He is slowly recuperating, although his mood does not seem to have improved with his health, as I learned when I entered to deliver one of the bushels of flowers that his well-wishers have left on the Citadel doorstep. 

All in all, a shaking experience, but we are all the wiser for it, I suppose. One day we shall look back fondly and say, "My Lord, do you remember when you caught on fire and tried to destroy everything? Ah, those were the days."

I shall take my leave now, for this entry grows long, and still more flowers accumulate on the landing.

Yours, 
Falangorn

And before them stood Skrawg, a vision of perfection. But alas, the life of a soldier does not lend itself to such pursuits, and further I rather doubt she is even aware that I exist, even after I had the Black Roses delivered to her doorstep. A good battle ought to clear my senses again... but such a delightful torment it is. Yours, Falangorn

8th of Eating, Y5 11:23:09 am NST I had a lovely surprise this morning, OneDayMore came to the Citadel to visit. Quite a lady, she is ~ her rather cheerful exterior hides a warrior's heart. She fought for our Lord Darigan during the battle to reclaim the Orb, and has a few scars to show for it (with much pride, of course). After a pleasant brunch, she revealed the true motive of her visit: She had brought along her weapons. "I'm not using these now," she explained. "Why don't you keep them?" She opened her satchel to reveal a fine armory, indeed. I must confess to a pang of jealousy, but as it is now my turn to wield them, that soon faded. I am eager to test my skills ~ and theirs ~ against a worthy opponent. Now, if only I could come across a set that would fit Ripper's paws... Yours, Falangorn

2nd of Eating, Y5 12:59:15 pm NST Today is, of course, Shoyru Day. A peculiar species, in my opinion, but not one shared by many it would seem. They possess some of the darkened grace of our Lord Darigan, with their horn-tipped wings, but then they seem to lose it all somewhere with the giant eyes and round heads. Their apparent popularity is, frankly, mystifying to me. Though perhaps not a fair analysis, as I've only met few individual Shoyrus ~ one of whom, being a mutant, is surely not representative of the species as a whole. There is one, Lord Severus by name, who often takes tea with Lord Malfoy, and he seems a noble fellow, if a little strange. I dare not say so while his owner is present, she has a great many curses and magical scrolls that make even my heart quiver with dread. And of course, the famous Antorcha, whom I have not had the honor to meet first-hand, but I saw her often above the fields of battle. Follower of the traitorous Skarl she may be, but a bold and fearless fighter, and she has my respect for that. No doubt our victory would have been even more complete were she not in their ranks. Later I shall write a little more about myself, my history and such, but I must away, as dear little Ripper is eating the curtains. Yours, Falangorn
